large proportion of instances is the only guide we profess to the
nature of the being which formed it

The new classification which he proposes, whilst in many
many respects an improvement upon that of M. D'Orbigny, is essentially
vitiated by this defect; and being in itself, therefore, just as provisional
as that for which it is proposed as a substitute, can scarcely be
expected to supersede it. My own researches I offer simply as
<u>materials</u> to serve as a <u>basis for classification</u>; feeling assured
that the time is not yet come, in which the superstructure can
be erected with any prospect of <s>a</s> permanent <s>existence</s> stability 

I shall commence with a minute analysis of one
of the lowest types, <u>Orbitolites</u>; and propose then to show
that <u>Orbiculina</u> and <u>Alveolina</u>, though ranked in a different
order by M. D'Orbigny, are in reality closely allied to it; whilst
a new genus (<u>Cycloclypeus),</u> which, in M D'Orbigny's arrangement, would rank
close to Orbitolites as a Cyclostèque, is physiologically separated
from it by the widest possible interval.
